been the most solomon day to me that I have seen since I left hoe. Nothing but experience can teach any one my feelings. Surely the western plains is the place to try mens souls. The fatigue and length of the journey, the exposure to a variety of weather in a strange climate, and the absence of civilized society, all tended to iritate, and beget within the human heart partial inhumanity and despreation. But God, the Author of the Universe who knows many hearts can comfort the weary traveler; even in this land of desolation.
Monday 12th At 8 AM we again moved on. Our road for a distance of 8 miles was good. We then reached the toll bridge at Thomas Fork. The road for 11 miles after crossing the fork was very rough and mountainous. We then struck Bear river where the road was comparatively level. It being 3 PM we halted and graced our mules. At 5 we again rolled until near sun-set, when we camped in a valley near a small stream of water. Here musquetoes were so numerous, and the keen demands of their appetites so great, that we were obliged to fight or lose a portion of our

July
Thursday 15th at 7 AM we rolled out of camp. At a rapid pace we trudged along over lofty hills and though deep vallies till midday when we camped for noon in a valley on the shore of mud creek. At 1 1/2 PM we again moved on till dark. We then camped on hill near

July
About 1 1/2 miles from camp we saw a soda spring. This is something in the works of nature that fills the mind of the Beholder with wonder and admiration It is situated on a rock (which stands in the valley) abut 20 feet from its base. The water flows from the top of conic rock about 3 feet high. Its waters is strongly pregnated with Soda, though perfectly pure. 3/4 of a mile farther on  we saw a beer spring, so called from its water being pregnated with beer or something with a similar taste (probably gass) 1/2 mile farther, on the bank of Bear rivers, we saw steamboat spring. This, if possible exceeds the other. It is situated on the brink of Bear River and in an exceeding romantic and interesting spot. It boils from a solid rock and has the appearance of a boiling pot. The water is often thrown in drops and small columes to a highth of from three to six feet. It is warm, and strongly pregnated with soda.

July
where we found good grass and plenty of it. At an early hour our Captain ordered friend Matthewsen & I to eat a cold supper & take our blankets & repair to the mountains to watch the mules (It being our turns to wach) We accordingly took our bed clothes, a piece of bacon, some rice, biscuit & crackers and started. Having arrived, we built a fire & cooked our suppers. After supper we made our bed in the open air, and waited for midnight when we were to begin our task. About 10 o clock a four or two legged mountaineer ran through our drove and created a stampede. As the frightened drove approached the spot where we were sleeping their noise waked me and I had just to rise & turn their course or should have been run over. We then in company with the guard for the forepart of the night carefully searched for the intruding stranger but did not find him. As soon as the mules became quiet we returned to bed. At midnight we were aroused to commence our duty; which we did and continued till 6 Sunday morning. We passed this day 8 graves.

a ravine in which there was water & plenty of wood. During the day we forded several small streams. To day we passed 2 graves.
Friday 16th At 7 AM we caught our mules & again started on our journey. 1 miles from cape we crossed the will muddy creek. This is a small stream whose banks are thickly covered with growing willows, and are also extremely soft & muddy. 8 miles farther we reached gravel creek. Here we camped for noon. Feed was poor & wood scarce. At 2 PM we broke camp and moved onwards till near sun set when we camped in a valley where there was no water & but little wood. In the afternoon our road was tolerable good, we asscended & descended a lofty hill or mountain in one the slope was graduel the other was steep and very stony. Today we passed 1 grave.
Saturday 19th At 1/2 past 6 we rolled out of camp over lofty hills and through deep ravines we trudged along (halting at noon as usual) till 6 PM we then camped by the roads side near a spring of good water. The feed in or near camp being very poor we were obliged to take our mules one mile from camp in a ravine

July
we find the reminants of waggons harness & scores of dead cattle and occasionally a dead mule or horse lay along the road side.
Tuesday 21st At 7 AM we struck our tents & moved on, till noon. We then as usual, stopped and grazed our mules. At 1 PM we again started. Over an undulating road we tugged along little thinking that bad luck is liable to overtake the weary traveler in all places. About  ((8)) PM the skanes of one end of the fore axle of No 4 broke. We were thus disabled in a barren land, with nothing to mend the broken. But as luck would have it one of our boys found on an old camping ground, the very article we needed. We then found a suitable place, and camped; The cripled waggon was then taken in hand & ere day light had gone, it was ready to roll on. Our road to day has been good. The weather hot & we passed 1 grave.
Wednesday 21st At an early hour we left camp. During the forenoon we passed a variety of scenery; among which was Pyramid circle. It consist of multitudinous rocks, ranging fro 10 to 15

July
Sunday 18th We remained in camp. Our mules being a distance from camp some of the company (as their turns came) were obliged to watch them; while others spent most of the day in cooking. I spent nearly all day in the tent having done my duty in the mess in the morning. Our road for several days, has been truly romantic. Lofty mountains of various shapes, deep ravines, and shady groves of Poplar bound it on each side, small streams, bordered with thrifty growing wills, occasionally cross it & often for miles follow along its side, then suddenly disappears behind the mountains. O, there is wisdom and grandeur displayed in the works of Nature!
Monday 19th At 7 AM we struck our tents & began another weeks travel toward our place of destination. Our road in the forenoon was somewhat undulating & lay mostly between 2 chains of mountains. At noon we halted at the entrance of a large valley. We traveled all the afternoon in the valley & camped for at night near raft river with plenty of water but no wood. The road was first rate, descending nearly all the way. Today we passed 3 graves. We have now come to a region where

July
we moved on a distance of 9 miles and camped in hot spring valley. This valley is so called from the numerous hot springs (It is sometimes called thousand spring valley from the same cause (this valley also contains a number of cold springs) Wood and water in camp to night is scarce. 2 graves to day
Saturday 24th At 7 AM we rolled out of camp. About 10 we passed a number of hot springs.They are scattered over about one acre of land, and are hot enough to boil eggs. At noon we halted on a hill side whe feed was tolerable, sage plenty, but no water. After noon we traveled over an undulating road till about 5 o clock, we then camped in a large beautiful valley where feed was first rate, water and wood very scarce. The day has been very hot. The road very dusty. 1 grave to day
Sunday 25th This Lord's day we also spent in came. At 1 PM our Captain addressed us in the language of exhaustation. His remarks were appropriate & profitable. I felt benefited by them.
Monday 26th At 6 we rolled out of camp. Nothing of note transpired during the day but we moved on

July 
feet in highth of various shapes tapering from the ground to the top. On these rocks are written the names of thousands of travelers. At noon we halted in a valley and graced our mules. At 1 PM we again rolled on to Goose creek, where we camped for night. Our road to day has been very rough. We asscended all day. We passed 2 grave.
Thursday 22nd At the usual hour we packed sack and baggage & at more than usual speed traveled toward our place of destination. At noon we halted as usual. Four miles from our camp at noon, we left goose creek, and traveled 12 miles to spring valley. It being 10 PM. when we arrived, we of course camped. Our road to day has been generally good. It runs over hills, 4 mountains, & through vallies, through deep ravines &c 1 grave to day.
Friday 23rd Feed being poor we harnessed and started without breakfast. After driving 4 miles we found tolerable feed. we here stopped cooked our breakfast & grazed the mules. After breakfast we rolled on (weather very hot) At noon we stopped where there was no wood nor water. Having nooned our usual time

July
Two of our men are now sick though not dangerously. 1 grave today.
Thursday 29th We left camp at the usual hours. Our course lay chiefly along the river (During the forenoon we passed through a deep & interesting ravine. Mountains of rocks of curious shapes stood bold & permanent on each side of the road as if to protect it & those who chance to travel it from invading foe. At noon we camped by the river and in consequence of sickness we remained in camp the remainder of the day. The weather is very hot & the road extremely dusty. 2 graves to day.
Friday 30th The sick being a little better we rolled out of camp at an early hour. Our road in the forenoon was extremely stone, dusty & hilly. In the afternoon it was nearly level, less stony, but still dusty.       Our travel in the afternoon was in the valley of the Humbolt. We are now traveling in a somewhat interesting and romantic region. The mountains

July
unmolested by every species of trouble. Soon after leaving the valley in which we were camped, we entered a deep ravine, about 4 miles in length. This is truly an interesting spot a little stream of pure water bounded by thrifty growing willows gayly flows through it & 2 large warm springs come rustling from the foot of the mountain. Having reached the end of the ravine, we entered another beautiful and fertile valley in which we saw acres of wild & thrifty growing rye. We traveled in this valley till 6 p.m. when we camped on the Humbolt river. Wood scarce, water plenty, grass good. We passed two graves to day.
Tuesday 27th At 6 AM we renewed our journey. Our course to day, lay along the Humbolt, through the same fertile valley, we traveled yesterday. Some of our company to day began to feel unwell & complain of extreme pain. 3 graves to day.
Wednesday 25th Still we are traveling in the beautiful valley of the Rio Humbolt. feed is good, wood scarce, water tolerable... At night we camped in the same valley.

August
clear & current rapid. It also abounds in fish; but they are not easily caught.
Sunday August 1st In view of one being in an unhealthy region, our Captain thought it best to travel toward our place of destination. This we accordingly did. Through the rich and beautiful valley of the Humbolt (halting at noon) as usual) till near 5 PM when we forded the river & camped on its south bank. The weather is hot & roads good.
Monday 2nd We rolled out of camp at 5 AM During the forenoon we passed through the last canyon that lay on our road between the Sierra Meadra, & Sierra Nevada. At noon we halted as usual. Having moved our usual length of time we again rolled out through the wide and noble valley of the Humbolt till night. We then camped by the river side where feed was torable but wood scarce. We passed 15 graves, nearly all of which

July
are less lofty. The vallies wider & feed better; than that we met with a few days ago. We have reached a region where the mountains are not so lofty as to think it beneath them to wear any other than snow white caps of the same color of their foundation. At night we camped by the side of the flowing Rio Humbolt. The days travel did not prove beneficial to the sick in the train.
Saturday 31st At 6 AM we rolled on. One mile & 1/2 from camp we forded the river. At noon we camped by the river side, feed first rate. Having nooned our usual time we moved on till night; when we again camped in the beautiful valley of the Humbolt. The sick today is a little better. We are now traveling in a valley so wide that the eye cannot reach across it. It abounds in grass wild sage, wild grain, willows &c It is watered by the swift flowing Humbolt, whose waters are

August 
camped in the rain, without wood or feed & retired to bed without supper.
Thursday 5th In view of the scarcity of feed for our mules we packed bag & jack at an early hours and with out breakfast rolled on a distance of 3 miles where we found some grass. There we cooked our breakfast & stayed till 11 AM giving our animals time to graze & rest. At 11 we again began to move over the sandy plain. The country here presents barrenness and desolation on every hand. Little else than wild sage & greese wood can be seen growing on its sandy surface. To day some of our mules began to lag. Old Charley came near giving out entirely. We camped about six PM about 200 yards from the river. Grass tolerable. Wood scarce. The health of the company is good except Mr Thronton, who is now sick with the mountain fever. One grave today.
Friday 6th At 7 AM we threw the leather on our rassle jacks and again

August
had been dug open and the bones of some who had been laid there exposed to view. They had (no doubt) been opened by Indians in search of plunder.
Tuesday 3rd. We struck our tents at an early hour and again moved toward the end of our journey. The road was excessively dusty & in some places for miles the sand was from four to eight inches deep. Our mules labored hard to draw their loads. The region through which we passed to day is barren & unpleasant little else than wild sage & greese wood grows in its sandy surface. At night we camped about 3/4 of a miles from the road by the river side. Feed was tolerable & wood scarce. One grave today.
Wednesday 4th At an early hour we pulled up stakes & rolled on Over an extremely sandy & dusty & rough road we rolled along over bluffs & through valleys we moved along with eyes filled with dust and clothes covered with the same till 9 PM when we

August
it lies the big meadows which so often cheers the hearts of the care worn travelers. Here they may rest & recuit their teams and prepare for the troubles common to the latter end of the rout.
Sunday 8th This beautiful & pleasant day of The Lord we spent (till 3 PM) in preparing for our journey across the 50 mile desert At 3 PM all thing being ready we moved on about dusk we reached a traiding post situated at the edge of the desert. We here watered our teams and rolled on, choosing rather to travel over the desert in the night than under the scorching rays of the sun. We had not traveled far on the desert when one of our boys picked up a human skull. Several of us examined it, and felt to sympathise with its unlucky owner. about 9 in the evening one of the wheels of waggon No 4 (the waggon belonging to my mess) ran off. We now found ourselves involved in trouble. We looked a long while

August
staggered toward the land of excitement. Through deep & burning sand from 4 to 10 inches deep we tugged along through a barren region till 3 p.m  when we reached the valley of the Humbolt. We then halted & let our animals graze; after which we rolled on a distance of about 3 miles and camped.
Saturday 7th We spent fore part of the day in cutting grass & drying it to carry on the desert for our animals. About 10 AM our Captain called the company together to hear their minds on the propriety of excusing three of our number who wished to leave the company & pack through the rest of the journey. By a vote of the company three mules and their portion of the property were given them & they were excused. (Their names A & J Steward & J Loux) At noon we pulled up stakes & rolled on till night when we camped in the same valley. This is an extensive valley situation on the sink of the Humbolt. In

August 
making up our minds to pack our mules and go ahead. But a second thought ran over our brains. We again raised the axle, put the wheel on & took a nut from the hind axle & put in the pace of the last one, and put the leather one on the hind axle. Hope again revived and we moved on. At 3 1/2 AM Monday we overtook the rest of the train which had halted to feed their teams. Some of the grass they had brought with them. We of course followed suit. At 4 AM we moved on at distance of 3 or 4 miles where we stopped & cooked our breakfast & gave our teams the remainder of our grass & a little water from our water cags. Day light having returned we could plainly see the marks of misery & distruction that had gone before us. The ruins of waggons; cattle & horses without number met our eyes on every side. About 9 AM we reached a region of deep & heavy sand

August
in the dark for the nut but could not find it. Friend Matthewson then consented to take the heal of his boot to supply the place of the lost nut. A holes then bored through it the size of the screw on the end of the skane on which it was placed. Being thus temprorally righted up we again rolled on; but soon the leather nut came off, and down went the axle. We looked a short time for the lost heel, but did not find it. Friend M then offered his other book as a sacrafice to the luck and chance of a journey on the desert. Having put the other boot heel in the place of a nut, we again moved a head; but soon a crash was heard and down went the axle the 3rd time. On examination we found that the boxes in the wheel were broken. We now began to think we should be obliged to pack our mules and leave the waggon but luck often cheers the traveler. We realized our condition in a desert land, and were about

August
recruiting ourselves & animals as far as time and circumstances would admit. At 3 PM two of our boys took 8 mules and went on the desert after the waggon that was left. They returned with it at 10 in evening
Wednesday 11th At 7 AM we again pulled up stakes & rolled onward. At 1 PM we stopped & let our mules graze there being no grass nearer than sixteen miles of this place. After an intermition of 2 hours we rolled on over a very stony road till near sunset. We then camped on the bank of Carson river in the valley of the same name. We now being to feel near our journeys end. Having less than 150 miles to travel yet. We passed 15 graves to day. Our teams though they have seen some hard times look comparatively well. The health of the company is good except Mr. Thomaston who is still struggling with the mountain fever but his is gradually mending

August
We here found it necessary for all except the driver to travel on foot. Slowly and laboriousilly we trudged along through the burning sand (occasionally passing a traiding post, erected for the relief of the suffering traveler) till 10 AM when the cam of No 2 gave out and we were obliged to leave the waggon. The team, and the remainder of the train, then moved on till about 1 PM when we reached Carson Valley through which runs a beautiful river of the same name. We here watered our thirsty mules and drove about 1 1/2 miles down the river where we camped. At the entrance of this valley is situated a number of large traiding posts where various articles of refreshment are kept for sale, though at an exorbitant price. I purchases a small bottle of pickles for $1,50. 12 graves to day.
Tuesday 10th This day we remained in camp. We spent the day mostly in

Saturday 14th At 7 AM we again packed bag and sack and tackled rassle jack  and with different feelings and a variety of opinions we rolled toward our place of destination. The road was more or less sandy. At 11 AM we passed over a steep and sandy Bluff and landed in the  most beautiful valley I ever saw. About 150 yards to the right of the road as it enters the valley is situated a splendid grove of lofty pines (in which we camped to spend the remainder of the day and the Sabbath) This looked indeed like civilization in the wilderness. The valley is bounded on the N.N.W. by a smooth & barren mountain; on the S by

August
Thursday 12th At the usual hour we rolled out of camp and made progress toward our journeys end. Our course lay chiefly along the bank of the river. During the day we passed several small traiding posts. At night we camped in the valley under the shade of thrifty growing cotton-wood trees. This valley abounds in grass willows & cotton wood trees.
Friday 13th At the usual hour we again started. At noon we camped near a traiding post where one of our buys exchanged some bacon for pork. This we found to be a rarity. During the afternoon we passed a canyon in which there was several miners at work. It was said that they avariged $50 per day. We also passed 3 traiding posts and crossed an 8 mile desert. At night we again camped in Carson Valley, near another traiding post where we exchanged some bacon for beef. This we also considered as quite a treat.

August
road increased in steepness as we advanced, we found it necessary to pack our riding mules with valises, provisions &c from the waggons to make it more easy for our teams to climb the mount before them. All day we tugged up the mountain over a crooked and sandy road. I carried a heave stone nearly all the way to block the wheel when we stopped to let our teams rest.About sunset we reached the summit. Then moved 1 1/2 miles farther and camped. This days travel ranks among the most interesting though the hardest and most difficult of any on our route thus far. Though we were rising higher at every step we could look in all directions and see peaks far above us. On the summit of these mountains it is so cold that an over coat would not be a burden.

August
one of a more irregular shape on which is thrifty growing pine and fir trees. About 1 mile from the entrance may be seen a beautiful little lake whose unrippled waters lie sparkling in the rays of firy faced Sol. A reflecting mind while viewing this lake hemed in by lofty mountains may learn a lesson that would be a benefit to the petulent and fretful. A lesson on composure & contentment, that might touch the case of the whole of the human race. This valley also affords grass in abundance.
Sunday 15th We remained in camp till 4 1/2 PM. We than packed and moved distance of 5 or 6 miles up the valley and again camped. 
Monday 16th At an early hour we again started for the land of Gold. At 7 AM we reached the foot of the Sierra Nevada. For awhile we tugged up the mountain side, but finding the

August
the shore of the mountain lake. There being a little grass here, we halted and let our mules graze. This being done we again rolled on toward the foot of the mount. Night came & we camped (on another grassy spot) for the night. Our road to day has been very rough a somewhat difficult.
Thursday 19th We started at the usual hour, and slowly made our way (over one of the worst roads I sever saw) down the mountain. At 1 PM we reached grass balled and camped for the rest of the day. This is a beautiful valley surrounded by snow capped mountains. whose sides abound in lofty pines and cedars it afforded an abundance of grass & good water.
Friday 20th At 6 1/2 AM we again harnessed our mules & again began to climb the mount. Soon we came to what we called the 1/2 miles pitch. It is very steep and stony & it was with some difficulty that we asscended it. Having reached the desirable end of this half miles we again began

August
Tuesday 17th To day we remained in camp on the top of the mountains; plenty of snow in sight, and too much cold wind for convenience or comfort. Mr B's train not being able to reach the summit yesterday some of our boys with three of our teams (for B's were about used up) and went and helped him to the summit. Others with guns in had and blood in their eyes went a hunting for grizzly bears, deer () But they found no game. In the morning I shot twice at a wolf. The first time I muffed him, the 2nd hit him in the same place. Sol at length sank behind the mount & we straitened ourselves on our pallets, shut or lookers for another nights sleep.
Wednesday 18th At 7 we pulled up stakes and rolled along. Over vexatious rocks, through the brush & down the mountain side, we tugged along till we reached a nearly level spot of earth, situated on

August
hour and rolled along over lofty mountains and through deep ravines (and over a road that is bad enough to make a child strike his father) till 1 PM when we reached a better and more level piece of road. 5 miles farther on we passed a traiding post where we purchased some salt, cheese ( ) 3 miles farther we camped for the night. Thus far good luck has followed us.
Monday 23rd At the usual hour we started with life and energy purposing to finish our journey before night. Having traveled 8 miles we reached a traiding post, we have camped and drove our mules 1 1/2 miles on a ranche where we were to give $3 a piece for month. We were to remain in camp till our Captains return from Colona.
Tuesday 24th We are still laying on our ears. Nothing to note has transpired during the day - our Captain not having returned we are still obliged to remain in camp.
Wednesday 25th The day passed with us the same as yesterday.

August
to descend over one of the most God forsaken waggon breaking mule provoking driver perplexing heart sickening roads I ever saw. Over rocks & down short & steep pitches over logs & through mud nearly deep enough to take a mule in out of sight, we pushed along fully determined that the Sierra Nevada should not conquer the NY boys. Night came & we again turned in. The feed was good.
Saturday 21st At the usual hour we again moved on. Our traveling to day was up and down the mountain as it had been for days before. The road still extremely rough, the mountains high and steep. While on the mount top we see huge banks of snow far below us. Night came and we, tired and hungry camped in ravine where there was water, but no grass. The mountains are covered with large and thrifty growing pines & cedars.
Sunday 22nd Our provisions having run short, we were compelled to travel. We accordingly started at an early

August 1852
Sunday 29th This Lords day I spent at the forest house. Here there is but little chance for retirement or meditation. The bustle of week day business is carried on the same as other days regardless of the Sabbath. All seem to have forgotten the divine command "Remember the Sabbath to keep it holy"  GOLD is the object of every man and the best means of obtaining it is their aim and study.
Monday 30th About 10 AM I went to Yankee Pines and spent the rest of the day. Nothing of note transpired within my observation. The Town was thriving with the active business of life. At night I returned to the forest house.
Tuesday 31st I spent the forenoon at the forest house. This is a rude looking house, built for the accomodation of miners & travelers. Lofty pines & cedars surround it on every side. After noon I went to Volcano bar; a distance of 2 miles situated on the middle for of the American river. Here may be seen the eagerness with which men are seeking for Gold. The marks of untiring indust-

August
Thursday 26th We still remain in camp. Nothing of note has transpired to day.
Friday 27th We spent the day in dividing the company stock. This occupied the whole day. The amount falling to each man is one hundred Dollars & ninety one cents. Our company has now disbanded, and begins to scatter. We no doubt shall never meet again.
Saturday 28th Our company is disbanded and some has already gone in different directions seeking their fortunes. At 6 AM I in company with ((yis) mess started for Yankee Pines ( a distance of 8 or 10 miles) ON our way, we stopped at the forest house and took breakfast. We here left our baggage & went on our way and reached the Town about 11 AM. My business there was to sell my mules which I did as soon as possible; I then in company with 3 others returned to the forest house & stopped for the night.

September 1852
Saturday 4th After breakfast we went to Yankee Pines and made preparations for mining. After spending the day in a variety of ways, we went to ((Dr C's)) and put up for the night
Sunday 5th After breakfast Mr W and I went to the forest house, where I stayed till 4 PM I then returned to Yankee Pines. Thus passed the day. My mind, and thoughts during the day, lingered around the old homestead, in my native State, and fresh to me was the memory of the days that have past.
Monday 6th I arose at an early hour, & in company with W, went to our claims where we intended commence mining. At breakfast time we returned; After breakfast we purchased a rocker, carried it to our claim, and began for the first time to search for gold. Our success for new beginers was very good. Night appeared and we ceased labor.
Tuesday 7th I spent the forenoon and a portion of the afternoon diging gold. The remainder of the

September 1852
-try meet the eye of the beholder in every direction. Near sunset myself & two others started on our return.Night overtook us before we had gone far up the hill. We then had to climb a very steep and difficult hill in the dark. About 8 PM we reached the forest house and put up for the night.
Wednesday Sept 1st I remained at the forest house all day. I spent the forenoon in repairing my clothes regulating the contents of my valises. Afternoon I studied head work, read the news &c
Thursday 2nd In the morning friend Steward & I went to Yankee Pines and borrowed some mining tools and prospected a portion of devils Canyon. We found gold in several places. At length we became tired & returned to the Hotel where we put up for the night.
Friday 3rd After breakfast we went to Volcano bar to see what the business prospect was; finding business dull, we returned to the forest house and turned in for the night

September 1852
and went rolling on a hay rack over hills and through ravines calling at each public house on the way till 4 PM when we reached the Village. Auburn is an enterprising town, teeming with the active business of a new and golden country. It is situated between two ranges of hills and is somewhat regular in the order and construction of its streets and buildings. The face of the country in its vincinity is undulating
Thursday 16th At 7 AM Mr Williams & I went to Dotas flats ( a distance of 4 miles from Auburn) in search of claims. On our way we passed through Ophir which is a thriving little village situated 3 miles from A another exceeds it in beauty and order. At noon we started on foot for Yankee pines via Auburn. We traveled till 5 PM when we arrived at the Grizzly Bears House and put up for the night.
Friday 17th We arose at an earl hours and started for Yankee Pines. At 10 AM we arrived. The remainder of the day I spent in thinking &c

September 1852
day in comparative idleness.
Wednesday 8th This day passed with me precisely the same as yesterday.
Thursday 9th Friend Steward and I spent the day in the mines. Our success for new beginers was ordinarily good. The weather is fine. The nights cool & days hot.
Friday 10th We spend the most of the day in the same old claim. The remainder comparative idleness, Our success was rather poor.
Saturday 11th We spent the forenoon in the mine, the afternoon in writing. The day has been extremely hot.
Sunday 12th I spent the day in meditation writing &c this seems to be the day for business. But few seem to know when Sabbath comes. O how few are the Christian privaliges in this place (Yankee Pines)
Monday 13th I spent most of the day in working my claim and the rest in prospecting.
Tuesday 14th Precisely the same as yesterday.
Wednesday 15th After breakfast Friend W & myself hired our passage to Auburn ( a distance of 20 miles)

September 1852
brook that was running though the Canyon to enable us to give our new found claim a more thorough trial. But we did not succeed in turning the stream. The afternoon I spent in idleness & went a hunting.
Thursday 23rd This day we spent in sinking a shaft in hopes of finding Aurum in greater abundance. But Sol sank out of our sight before our task was done. We then returned to the town. Thus passed the day.
Friday 24th In the forenoon W & I finished our task of yesterday. After noon we went down the canyon in search of a new claim. Having found one we again returned to town. Thus passed the day.
Saturday 25th In the forenoon we built a dam, and ditch down the Devils Canyon for the purpose of turning the water off our claim. Afternoon we prospected on Bloomer Hill.
Sunday 26th The same routine of business is followed that is general through the week. I spend most of the day in my room and the remainder in different parts of the village.

September 1852
Saturday 18th I spent the forenoon in the Village. After noon I done some washing, digging &c

The sound of the church gong bell, and the voice of the ministers of God, are not hear. But their place is filled with idle chit-chat, gambling, and licenciousness.
Monday 20th I spent the day in prospecting, but without success.
Tuesday 21st Friend W and I shouldered our mining tools, and went up Devils Canyon on a prospecting tour. By dilligent searching we found the color, and with water and rocker began to wash. But did not find enough Gold to pay us for our trouble Night appeared and we returned.

The day which the Father of light has set apart for this service, the day which he has commanded all men to remember and keep it holy. But soon, regardless of the divine command, the rattle of business was heard throughout the length and breadth of the town (Yankee Pines) The Merchant threw open the doors of his house of merchandise, the Gambler spread his table with his gaming cards, and ill gotten gain, and prepared to gain or lose at games of chance; The Teamster harnessed his team, and started on his tour of worldly business, the Miner shouldered his tools and started for his claim purposing to spend another day in increasing his stock of worldly goods. The Blacksmith The Carpenter, the Tinner and all seemed to have forgotten the interest of the Soul, and were straining every nerve to swell their stock of perishable wealth. Devils Canyon. A rush was made by many of the people of the Town to see what the trouble was, and to relieve the suffering On reaching the bridge we found that the Stage loaded with passengers had run off the bridge. The passengers were hurt more or less, but it was thought that none dangerously. The driver having neglected to lock the wheels at the top of the hill leading to the bridge, the team was unable to hold back their load. It then commenced running and kicking. Being under such headway they were unable to turn at the end of the bridge, and consequently the team stage passengers and all were thrown from the bridge a distance of twelve to twenty feet. The Stage was broken in pieces and one of the horses badly hurt.

We here saw the effect of the autum miner's labor. The river had been raised from its bed, by  means of dams and flumes And the miner was searching its bed for gold. Thursday 25th In the forenoon we made our sluices. Afternoon we washed for Aurum. During the afternoon we saw several Indians going at quick time toward our Cabin. Friz shouldered his shovel and started for the Indians. When he got in sight of the Cabin he saw the Native standing in the door with his hands full of our life preservers. He instantly yelped at the Indians and it would have done you good to have seen them stampede over the hill. I ordered Friz to scalp three of them. As we approached the city, our eyes were greeted with the sight of well cultivated fields, clothed with a great thrifty growing vegetables and the marks of peace, comfort, and contentment. About 1 AM we reached the American river which we crossed on a ferry boat. At 9 we found ourselves in the City. December 1852
Cattle horses mules and sheep. A little after sun set we reached San Jose Mission and put up for the night having traveled 35 miles during the day. The mission consists of several Spanish and some American houses and a Catholic church. Many of the former are built of mud, and covered with clay. And (as I was told) had stood for nearly 100 years. The old church also built of mud, bears the marks of time in every feature. Its walls are spotted with age, its clay covered roof that has shield it sacred interior from the fierce pelting of 1000s of storms, presents a somewhat confused appearance. Its 4 bells now rusted with age, still hold their positions in its scared walls, always ready to call together the worshipers. The very sight of the whole fabric is enough to fill the beholder with a reverential awe. While looking I felt as if I had ben placed by some unseen hand back to the old days of yore.

Sunday 26th This Lords day I spent in reading, conversing, meditating upon the past, present, future &c. The forenoon I spent on the premises of my employer. Afternoon I went to Mr H and saw friend Knowles. 
Monday 27th To day I helped the H's haul lumber & bolts to the ford of the Coyote.
Tuesday 28th To Day we hauled the above lumber & bolts across the Coyote & to their farm. Night appeared before our task was done. We however finished & went to Mr Me's and put up for the night.
Wednesday 29th In the morning according to orders I went about 2 1/2 miles to return a borrowed wagon, After which I saddled the mules and started for H's farm. In order to make a cut off I ventured to try a new ford. I here found the stream so deep that the jacks were obliged to swim. The current was so strong that myself & mules were carried about 100 yards down the stream before we could reach the opposite shore. I worked through the day in my wet clothes & at night returned home. Thus passed the day.
Thursday 30th My business to day was of a miscellaneous character; ranging from making wedges, to timber searing & hawing

Thursday 23rd. Sure enough' the same old six pence. Enough to give a fellow the back ache.

Near San Jose while crossing a wide & difficult slough, our wagon swamped; and in trying to release ourselves & team we broke the wagon ((meap)). Saturday 25th Though this may be a merry Christmas to some it is not to me. The day was very rainy & cold. In the forenoon I choped stove wood, afternoon I spent in idleness.

January 1853
Friday 31st The Coyote being impassable on account of recent rains I could not go to the farm of my employer, and was obliged to remain at Mr H's where I spent the day in a miscellaneous manner.
Saturday January 1st My thoughts at the appearance of the first morning of 1853 may better imagined than told. With a sign, I contracted my present condition with that of one year ago. I thought how changable is the human mind, and how variable the scenes of life. What a varied of changes can take place within the space of one short year. Many who one year ago were in the full enjoyment of life and health, are now beneath the sod, Many who were in affluent circumstance have been reduced to insolvency, while others have become rich. Many who had been long absent from home have returned while others have left their homes and kindred friends for the regions of excitement & strife. The latter seem to be my condition. Tis long since I joined in the lively and cheerful converse of the kindred circle. But notwithstanding the privations of a life in California my spirits are still good and my confidence and trust is in the

We spent the forenoon at driving pickets. Afternoon we cut and wound didoes, and sharpened pickets.
Thursday 24th The wind blew a gale nearly all day. Being out of business we spent the day in comparative idleness. We spent the forenoon and around the tent. Afternoon we crossed the Coyote and visited our claim, thence to Mr H's. after a few moments conversation with Mr H about claims &c H offered each of us a mule to ride and to pilot us to an unoccupied claim on the east side of the valley. We accepted and soon were astride of the quadrupeds. (but not till Friz had been floored by ole' Ben) Over the valley and over ditches we galloped along till we reached the claims mentioned. Having satisfied our curiosity we set out on our return. Being full of jokes and sport we soon fell into bragin; which soon brought on a race. having reached a straight and well trod portion of the road. Friz ran by me. Monday 28th During the forenoon we drove picket. Afternoon we surveyed a meadow of 60 acres for the purpose of mowing in due season. This occupied our time till 3 o clock The remainder of the day we wound Didoes.
Tuesday March 1st In the forenoon we wound Didoes. Afternoon we went to our claim and vamoused some trespassers, after which we returned to our cabin.
Wednesday 2nd This forenoon Friz & I went to town, searched the reckard to find out the true state of our claim and made a purchase of some articles of wear and tear & returned. Afternoon we worked at idleness.
Thursday 3 To day we wound Didoes for Mr ----

February 1853
with swinging hats and flying heels tried the speed of our donkeys. F rode a large mule will saddled and I a small one bare baked. But notwithstanding the disadvantages I win the race to the no small mortification of my opponent. Having reached H's we took care of our steeds and seated ourselves for an evening visit. The tenor of our conversation was of a lively and philosophic stamp. The evening being far spent we returned to our tent and retired for the night.
Friday 25th The day was rainy. In the forenoon I went to Asello and purchased a lexicon and spanish grammar. Afternoon I returned, mended my book &c.
Saturday 26th To day we cut and wound didoes.
Sunday 27th Another day of the Lord has dawned. A day which all mankind is commanded to remember and keep holy but allow how few there are who heed the Divine command; particularly in this land

March 1853
Monday 28th This forenoon I chopped fencing timber. Afternoon I cut potatoes. Firz harrowed the potatoe patch. To day we saw our old firend (Mr J Heydeliff) on pack and had a social time in recounting the scenes of our mining & life & the jollity of our life in the old slab cabin, and the feast on the ((prass)) of molasses candy.

Sunday 27th The day was cold, windy and rainy. I remained at the tent all day. I occupied the time in reading writing &c. Sabbaths to me are days of reflection. They are days in which I am liable to wish myself at home where I could enjoy the Lords day as I used to in former days. It is then, that I weigh perishable wealth in the Philosopher's seals, and look at the inconveniences of my situation in this nominal Ophry's of the United States far away from home and friends But still I do not court homesickness.

April 1853

Monday 4th This forenoon I cut didoes and Friz made a pair of bars. Afternoon we wound didoes and drove stakes.
Tuesday 5th It is now one year since  I left my native home. I have passed through many dangers and witnessed many changes since that time. Many degrees of longitude lie between me and the land of my sires. The contrast between my present position and that of one year ago is distinctly marked. The scenery of the past, the anticipations of the future and the reality of the present flash vividly over my mind. And whither I shall ever again reach my own native or not is only known to Him who holds the destinies of all mankind.
We drove stakes in the forenoon. Afternoon we planted potatoes

April 1853
While crossing the Coyote the team got into an offray, and came near turning us unto the stream and Friz, while in the act of jumping from the wagon caught his lower garment over a thumb nut and made an unfortunate rent therein.
Sunday 3rd Another day of  rest has appeared. All Nature seems hushed in silence. The Majestic  Luminary of the skies, arose from behind the eastern hills and gently traveled in his aerial path toward the western horizon. His face during the entire was not for a moment vailed by the clouds. All day the cattle were liesurely feeding about the tent, and the air rung with the musical notes of the feathered tribe. Several times during the day a lark alighted on the corner of the tent nearly over my head and sang its tunes of merriment as if it realized the presence of the day of the Lord and was singing its sweetest songs in praise and adoration

And, in spite of my endeavors to drive him from me, he continued to bray and follow me. Having followed me about one hundred fifty yards he left leaving me glad to get rid of his company.

April & May 1853
By Appleton
April Saturday 30th This day I went to town to see and hear of the prospect of the times. But times appeared rather dull. While in town, I fell into an argument with Book Seller on the Divinity of Christ the Divine oragin of the Bible, the Power of God, the policy of Different Denominations &c. My opponent being a anthiest of course we did not view the different subjects alike. Night drew near, and I turned homeward & arrived near sun set. Thus passed the day.
Sunday May 1st Still I find myself in the land of excitement far from home and kindred friends where Sabbaths and Sanctuary privaleges are not so highly appreciated as in my native State; my longed for home. I am still a Shaped Monument of God's mercy; a pensioner upon His bounty. I am still led to severe His name and feel to render thanks, and praise to him

Saturday 7th To day I took the bullocks to town to sell I found buyers plenty, but their pay did not suit. Night drew near and I returned.
Sunday 8th Sol has again arose above the eastern hills and began his silent and rapid march through the vault of Heaven. His shining face adds cheerfulness to the new born Sabbath and disclosed the beauties of nature that two hours ago were hid by the sable robe of night. Gentle Borca fans the valley with his health giving, and rendering

May 1853
for the protraction of life and health,and  the pertaining comforts. Although it is exceedingly unpleasant to be so far from home and friends and under the influence of temporal inconveniences; yet candid reasoning on the beauty of time, the longevity of man, the unconstancy of terrestrial things, the duration of Eternity, and the rewards of the finally faithful in the work of Bliss; I feel inclined to say that no part of earth is mans continued abiding place and reconcile myself to my lot. May 1853
poverty to wealth within a few days, while others have fallen from affluence to indigence. I have heard many of a sigh of homesickness from those who have been long from home and destitute of the means to convey them there. And have seen those who, in view of their being far from home, and out of refined Society, have thrown off restraint and become familiar with the Gambler, the Bachanalian, and the Debauchee. I have seen the Murderer condemned by the laws of his Country, hung between earth and sky. And have seen scores of the graves of the uncared for strangers, and death has snatched his victim withing six feet of where I was sleeping and not noise enough made by those in attendance to awake me.

When we succeeded in stoping them by means of the reins and

June 1853
the former) no sooner had Mr A mounted little major then he (feeling and hearing the rattle of the harness about his posterior) strick upon a wild and brisk stampede. Soon the saddle turned and Mr A landed on Terra Firma. And major soon disappeared among the mustard.  I mounted old bay and followed. Having rode about a mile, I found the little fellow tied to a post. I loosed him and brought him back. We then took a new start which proved successful.

We called (on our way) at town to get some lumber and while in the act of loading the first board A's hat blew off and fell between the caballos. This gave them another start and through the streets they ran with fearful confusion leaving the box in one place the hind wheels and axle in another, the fore wheels before the carpenter shop the whiffle trees before the Danadaria the near and fore axle before the largest traiding house in the city where the runaways were caught. We then called the wagon together, repaired damaged which was but very little) put on our load & returned smilingly home. Thus passed the Monday of June 24th 1853

which cut off his tail and ham cords, injuring him to such an extent that we all thought it proper to put an end to his life. The Dutchman was then appointed executioner. We accordingly shouldered the halbert and followed the dog. Having overtaken the wounded brute, he slowly and steadily raised the weapon of death and with herculean strength settled it upon the neck of the bleeding quardruped, which sent him instantaneously into annihilation. We then dragged him among the the wild oats and left him to the buzzard, the crow, and other unclean birds. Nothing else of note transpired during the day. Night appeared and we ceased labor.

Sunday 25th Another week has rolled around and the Sabbath has again appeared. The king of the day has appeared above the eastern horizon and is  rapidly winging his way through the spacious universe. The sable robe of night has fled before his shining face. The brightness and stillness of the day as usual causes me to think of home and long to be there. During the forenoon I wrote a letter to friend D- A-. wrote in my journal &c. Monday 19th After breakfast Friz and I went to town ((to see)) and arrange some matters relative to our ((comfro)) We remained in town till near night. During the day I noticed a crowd of people in and around the court house. Curiousity led me to go and see what had called so many together. I there saw a man stretched upon a board and covered with dirt who had been brutally murdered the night before by some desparado. It seems that he unfortunate man was on his way to his place of labor a few miles from town where he was overtaken by some villain or Villains who fired upon him the ball entering his back and lodged near his breast bone. Night appeared and we returend.

November 1853
turtle. About nine in the evening we arrived at Pares camp where we halted for the night. During the night a Spanish bull assailed our oxen goring them with his horns and causing them to call loudly (in their language) for help. We ran garbless to their relief & chased the assailant away then returned to our bed in the open air. 
Tuesday November 1st At length morning dawned. We then cooked,and ate our breakfast, and moved on farther in the mountain. About nine A.M. we reached the mouth of flume Cannon where we left our team and put our things aboard of another wagon that was going part way up the cannon. Having reached the end of the road we shouldered our goods and went about one half mile farther over logs rocks and brush. We then found a camping place and sat down to rest

October 1853
to roll toward the mountain. Hour, after hour we rolled along, endeavoring to shorten the time by social chitchat, singing &c. At noon we halted under a large sycamore on the shore of the Coyote where we ate a melon and fed our teams. We then rolled along. Having become tired of singing and converse, we began to watch the sun and count the distance we had to travel. At Sun-set we reached the seven mile house. We here bought some crackers and still rolled on eating as we went. Night having overtaken us we became inpatient to see the end of our journey and consequently we alternately swung and cracked the whip - not taking much pains to miss the oxens - for speed was what we wanted though we did not succeed in raising that which would far outstrip the speed of a (( muoe)))

November 1853
A short distance from where we stood we saw a small house. Curiosity led us to see who lived there, and what induced them to take up their abode in the isolated spot. We approached the house, and knocked at the door, but no on said come in. We then opened the door and went in. But found no one there to answer our questions. On searching the house we found various articles of house hold furniture but they appeared to have been untouched for years for they wee both rusty and dusty as was the whole interior or the house. On entering one of the upper rooms we saw in a mean berth the corpse of a man. K- instantly sprang into the berth by the side of the dean & said to me, I am to bed with a dean man. According to my proposition he left the berth, and we started on our return. When about half

November 1853
with heavy timber and the level was smooth and prairie like. At length we came to the foot of an extremely high and steep mountain. Notwithstanding our weariness our curiosity led us to assend. So we began slowly and carefully to climb the mountain. But did not look back till we reached the summit. We then turned to look upon what might be seen below. We could see lakes, rivers, mountains, hills, cities, towns villages and many of the multitude of occupations and vocations of the world. And could plainly see that the native power of those who were following this multitude of occupations was anticipated happiness. Among the multitude, there seemed to be none who raised their eyes above that which concerned their occupations and tended brighten their prospects of gaining the object of their pursuit

November 1853
way down the hill we met an old woman with her face covered with a black vail. I asked her about the house on the hill, and of its inanimate occupant. She said the house was built a great many years ago but exactly for what purpose she did not remember. But it had late years been used as a sort of hospital in which the sick were put and required to wait on, and doctor themselves (thought medicine was given them with directions how to use it at their entering the house) and if they got well it was good if not, they died uncared for and alone. Of the dead that we found in the house she said he had been taken there under the above circumstances about one year ago and had not been visited by his friends since. I asked her why they built their hospital so far off. She said their object was to put the sick where

Tuesday 22nd We sawed picket cuts in the afternoon. Each cut as we severed it from the main body of the tree would roll from the side of the mountain (where we sawed them) in the cannon below. Having lost our wedge during the down tumbling of the last cut in the forenoon we spent nearly all the afternoon in looking for it. Having looked thus far in vain we gave it up for lost and sawed another cut and ceased labor for the day.

Rule for the cube route in poetry
The cube of your first period take
And of the root a quotient make
This being done, then you must see,
That numbers straight divided be,
BY just three hundred time the square
Of what your quotient figures bear,
Last squared and multiplied by the rest,
And product thirty time expressed
The cube of your last figure too
You will add in if right you do
Repeat your work and so descend
From period to period to the end

January 1854

We merely glance our thoughts after the scenes of the past, and turn our minds to the future, without thinking to profit by the past and do better in the future, or seriously reflecting upon the fatal events of the year that was rolled into Eternity. But such is the make of the Human mind that no matter how serious, or how fatal the event of the present may be; as soon as they are past they are forgotten.

February 1854
of the upper deep seemed to be broken up. And unrestrained, and in large and plentiful drops the rain descends showing no respect of person, but falling upon all who dare venture from under shelter. we stayed in doors nearly all day.
Saturday 11th After breakfast I started for San Paso a distance of thirty miles. At the foot of the canyon I hired a horse which I mounted and went hipetty hop toward the city. About 5 o clock PM I arrived at Mr A's Business in the valley seems to be in a thriving condition. The farmers are busily engaged in putting in their seed in hopes of reaping a plentiful reward at the coming harvest. The unbroken soil is sending forth its carpet of green thus affording food for thousands of cattle, sheep & horses

the life preservers belonging to the trio. And each member of the disolved trio took his portion of the goods there of indeed the trio as a trio no longer exists. Its union bands have burst asunder without the aid of fire or smoke. And no unusual sound was heard at the bursting thereof. And shall the parts thus separated ever again reunite? Shall the already broken band ever be repaired so as again to enable the same trio? Forbid it my Countrymen! Forbid it good luck and prosperity!

Monday 22nd I butted one log before breakfast. The remainder of the day I spent in and about the mill
Tuesday 23 Still disengaged
Wednesday 24th Settled for our job
Thursday 25th (( This morning we settled with P andd took B- & Co note for the

May 1854
P- started on foot a distance of seven miles. Arrived too late for love feast. Love feast being over the doors were opened, and we with others entered. After a brief sermon and the adminiistering of the Sacrament the Rev announced the baptism which was to take place at four P.M. and closed the exercise
P- and I then started on our return home. Arrived about six P.M.
Monday 15th According to agreement between P- and myself and company, we employed men to measure our logs. After making the necessary arrangements we and they commenced the work. Al went off prosperous and in order Night appeared and we turned in
Tuesday 16th To day we measured also

May 1854
Sunday 28th In the forenoon I attended the M.E. Church South. Afternoon I went to Santa Clara where I saw two of my old school mates at home, and had a cheerful and interesting chat about home and the past scenes of our schooling days. Night drew near and I returned to San Jose. In the evening I attended church
Monday 29th After breakfast I engaged passage with Mr B- to the twenty one. I helped him load his wagon preparatory to a start. All being ready we rolled on . Arrived at five P.M. I then started on foot for B' & Co's mill, a distance of ten miles from the 21. Arrived at nine in the evening.
Tuesday 30th I spent the day in comparative idleness
Wednesday 31st Remained in the vicinity of my

May 1854
balance due us on our job. The rest of the day I spent about the cabin and mill yard
Friday 26th Spent the day about the mill yard as usual
Saturday 27th About eight A.M. I started in company with Mr B- for San Jose. We called at Mr M-'s shop, where B got his horse shod. After which we harnessed and hitched and rolled on. We next called at old Mother T-'s and took a segar &c. We then rolled on talking on the different subjects that our minds would dictate. Next at the Laguna &c., and again renewed our journey. Arrived at San Jose about four P.M. The remainder of the day I spent visiting different parts of the town, talking with old acquaintences &c.

June 1854
Friday 9th Slab cutting dust wheeling, wood whaling &c
Saturday 10th The same
Sunday 11th Remained at home as usual. During the day I wrote a letter to Sister Eley.
Monday 12th I began the labors of the week by whaling sawdust choping slabs and shealing wood
Tuesday 13th "-"-"
Wednesday 14th The same
Thursday 15th I worked on the road
Friday 16th Lo mismo
Saturday 16th I resumed my work about the mill
Sunday 18th I remained at home as usual
Monday 19th Commenced the labor of the by my usual work about the mill
Tuesday 20th The same
Wednesday 21st Soon after the mill started some of the boxes attached to the saw sash broke. Consequenly business went off rather dull till toward night

June 1854
cabin, studying a little head work &c
Thursday June 1st During the forenoon, I bargained with Thomas & Co to work in about about their mill. And agreed to commence work after noon. After dinner according to agreement I began in T- & Co employ by measuring logs; which too till about four P.M. the remainder of the day I chopped slabs
Friday 2nd I chopped slabs in the forenoon. Afternoon I carried lumber and wheeled saw dust
Saturday 3rd I peeled logs wheeled wood and sawdust
Sunday 4th Remained at home as usual
Monday 5th Worked at road building
Tuesday 6th La mismo
Wednesday 6th Still road building trucking, shoveling &c
Thursday 8th I sawed logs build road &c

June 1854
when, all being righted business began to ((snow))
Thursday 22nd business was lively all day
Friday 23rd La misma
Saturday 24th Rather slow. Socket brok the lever to his tightner
Sunday 25th I spent the day in reading, writing, talking, sleeping, thinging &c
Monday 26th I began the week by filling my usual place about the mill
Tuesday 27th Still the same unchanging monotony
Wednesday 28th Still wheeling dust and wood
Thursday 29th The same
Friday 30th " " "
Saturday July 1st In the forenoon wheeled wood and dust as usual. Afternoon I run the engine
Sunday 2nd Remained at home as usual
Monday 3rd Began the week by filling  my usual place about

July 1854
for the night.
Tuesday 11th I arrose at an early hour and fed, and carded my nag and made preparations for a return to the mountains. After breakfast I saddled and started. Called at Dr Lewis and took dinner then proceeded on my journey. Reached the mounts at six P.M.
Wednesday 12th I sawed logs
Thursday 13th Lo mismo
Friday 14th In the forenoon I sawed logs and cut slabs. Afternoon (the mill being closed for the rest of the week) I spent in idleness
Saturday 15th Spent in comparative idleness
Sunday 16th After breakfast O- and I went to his brother's (a distance of four miles) where we spent the most of the day. Toward night we started on our return. Arrived about six P.M.

July 1854
our Nation's birth day &c. Arrived home about 9 P.M. Thus passed Independence day
Wednesday 5th In the forenoon i worked about the mill. Afternoon I worked on the road
Thursday 6th In the forenoon I worked on the road. Afternoon in and about the mill
Friday 7th I worked in the mill
Saturday 8th La mismo
Sunday 9th Spent the day mostly in my cabin engaged in reading, writing &c
Monday 10th After breakfast I started for San Jose. About one o clock P.M. arrived at Mr A-'s where I stayed till about five P.M. A and I then hitched a nag to his buggy and went to la Pueblo. Having done our business there set out on our return to A-'s arrived soon after sun set.. Thus passed the day and I turned in

July 1854
and built a fire under his aquatic container. After stiring and adding fuel to the fire for about an hour the bowels of the monster began to show signs of great commotion withing. All being ready I opened the mouth of the snorting beast, and O' such hissing and snorting as is not often heard in the wilderness. Filling the air with his pot breath thrown out in notes & jets calling louder to all to stand at their posts & to the duties of another day. And simultaneously every member of his body moved and the sound of machines was heard throughout the length and breadth of the mill. All day Behemoth continued to rear and puff consuming much wood and drinking much water. At length the night appeared. I then closed his

Aug 1854
Monday 17th I worked on the road
Tuesday 18th Worked on the road in the forenoon, afternoon I worked at the mill
Wednesday 19th I worked at my usual business about the mill
Thursday 20th The same
Friday 21st La mismo
Saturday 22nd Still the same monotonous course
Sunday 23rd Stayed at home as usual
Monday 24th Commenced the week in my usual place about the mill
Tuesday 25th Still following the same
Wednesday 26th My birth day has again appeared. Finding me a choper or wood and whaler of saw dust.
Thursday 27th Still the same old sixpence
Friday 28th Lo mismo
Saturday 29th I arose at an early hour and oiled old Behemoth

August 1854
mouth and all sounds of machinery ceased.
Sunday 30th Spent the day at home engaged in reading, singing, writing &c
Monday 1st I filled the same old place about the mill
Tuesday August 1st The same in the forenoon. Afternoon I rand Behemoth non-varying monotony
Wednesday 2nd Wheeled sawdust &c as usual.
Thursday 3rd The mill being out of tune, old Behemoth was suffered to remain idle. I tinkered ((promiseuously)) about the mill during the day
Friday 4th In the fore noon I worked on the road: After dinner I fired up preparatory to a start (the mill being repaired) then resumed my old place.
Saturday 5th Still the same old sixpence
The End

By-Laws of Oneida, California Company
We , the undersigned citizens of the State of New York, being bound upon an expedition to California, and being desirous of forming ourselves into a Joint Company, having ((joint)) and mutual interest in all things pertaining to the welfare of said Company, agree, under a penalty to be hearafter affixed, to strictly observe the following rules:
Article 1st
Each member shall bear an equal proportion of the expenses incident to said expedition.
Article 2nd
A Committee of four, viz Messrs Yale, Steward, Brown, and Williams, shall precede the Company to Fort Independence, and purchase the necessary supplies from that point onward.
Article 3d
We agree that ((A Ake Oal YALE)) shall be a Captain or leader from Fort Independence onward, and the we will faithfully observe his order and counsel.
Article 4th
If any member having paid into the funds of said Co. his quota of money, and shall become incapable of going from sickness or other unavoidable circumstances, his money shall be refunded .
Article 5th
When the Company arrives at its destination, the property belonging to

said Company, shall be either divided equally, or shall be sold and the proceeds equally divided among the members of said Company as a majority of the Company shall direct.
Article 6th
If any of said Company shall, curing the route, become sick, or in any way incapacitated, he or they shall have good care and attendance from the balance of the Company, and his interest or advancement in no way impaired on account of said sickness or incapacity, during the journey.
Article 7th 
If any of the members of the Company shall wilfully violate any of the following rules, upon being adjudged guilty by a majority, he shall pay into the fund of said Company a sum of money not less than two dollars.
Article 8th
This agreement can at any time be altered or amended by a majority of the votes of the members of said Company
